text: the impact of the pandemic has been felt
very differently across the UK and
across generations young people have
been less likely to fall ill but
significantly more likely to lose their
jobs and face long term financial
problems and many of the young were
already struggling with employment or
burdened with student loans
Amol Rajan has been to rural
Warwickshire to speak to those now
rethinking their futures
deep in the heart of rural Britain these
ships turn young farmers ought to have
been enjoying a golden summer savoring
their freedom while on the cusp of their
careers instead the serenity of rural
water conceals the anxiety of a
generation who have seen their futures
delayed I just think people might change
their careers completely like there
might more towards like an eight NHS
career or even just like the farming
career nice job that's worth more
worthwhile than actually focusing on
just a big business like marketing in
London or something like that
just money stress you out it does from
being in a single-parent family that's
very stressful especially now my
mother's been furloughed so it's just a
bit stressful now and then but as long
as I still got a job that's fine now
we're all good just emotionally have you
found the whole experience of this
pandemic I feel like it's almost a rite
of passage to take your a-levels at the
end of school and it seems weird when I
talk in 20 years time and people ask me
what did you get in there a levels what
did you do I'll be like well I did them
but I didn't actually have to sit the
exams so there are definitely like
positives and negatives to it a survey
by the resolution foundation shows that
last month 18 to 24 year olds were
hardest hit in employment terms a third
of them have been furloughed or lost

and schools of shirts so you can't

so I think if you're in a four-year
apprenticeship there's a chance it could

obviously to actually pass through
you've got to qualify the co vid 19
hasn't affected me personally because

cows are still gonna be fed pigs are

because our farm shop has just gone

it's really good how do you feel being
part of a generation that is entering an

economic burden on us
I think our generations got quite a
large weight of responsibility on our
shoulders and we've got to make sure
that you know we've got we've got a lot
to pay into the system
I think we're expecting to be taxed and
I think you know there's a lot of money
being paid out and rightly so you know
every tax breaks on businesses and
people on furlough it's necessary it has
to be done so I think everyone just has
to play their part it's often been said
about this virus that we're all in it
together but actually each generation is
having a very different experience older
people are more likely to fall ill and
younger people already facing exorbitant
house prices or student loans are now
going to be burdened by huge new
national debts as well as their own come
on
raised in the shadow of a financial
